S4.T2.1.caption: Default hyperparameter settings for finetuning. The cells with two numbers present the values for FFT/LoRA. LoRA finetuning acts on very specific modules, and adds minimal trainable parameters, while keeping the rest frozen. This acts like an implicit regularization, and hence we do not add any explicit strategies like label-smoothing and dropout to the model in this setup.
S4.T2.1.table:
Hyperparameter Value
Global Max Tokens 32K
Optimizer Adam
LR scheduler inverse_sqrt
Gradient clip norm 1.0
Adam betas (0.9, 0.98) / (0.9, 0.999)
Checkpoint 1000 steps, BLEU @ k=5𝑘5k=5italic_k = 5
Patience 10
Max Positions (4096, 4096)
Warmup steps 2000
Learning rate 6e-5 / 1e-4
Dropout 0.2 / 0
Label smoothing 0.1 / 0
LoRA rank 16
LoRA alpha 32
LoRA dropout 0.05
LoRA Rank Scaled True
FP16 True
references: We use the fairseq777Our variant implements, LoRA, RoPE, ALiBi, and a slightly efficient SDPA as per the requirements of this work framework Ott et al. (2019) for all of our experiments. All the finetuning experiments were conducted on 4 ×\times× A100 80Gb GPUs, the train-from-scratch experiments on 8 ×\times× H100 80Gb GPUs, and every model was trained till convergence with early-stopping. The exact hyperparameter sets are mentioned in Tables 2 and 3.

S4.T3.1.caption: Default hyperparameter settings for training from scratch
S4.T3.1.table:
Hyperparameter Value
Global Max Tokens 256K
Optimizer Adam
LR scheduler inverse_sqrt
Gradient clip norm 1.0
Adam betas (0.9, 0.98)
Checkpoint 1000 steps, BLEU @ k=5𝑘5k=5italic_k = 5
Patience 10
Max Positions (4096, 4096)
Warmup steps 4000
Learning rate 7e-4
Dropout 0.2
Label smoothing 0.1
FP16 True
references: We use the fairseq777Our variant implements, LoRA, RoPE, ALiBi, and a slightly efficient SDPA as per the requirements of this work framework Ott et al. (2019) for all of our experiments. All the finetuning experiments were conducted on 4 ×\times× A100 80Gb GPUs, the train-from-scratch experiments on 8 ×\times× H100 80Gb GPUs, and every model was trained till convergence with early-stopping. The exact hyperparameter sets are mentioned in Tables 2 and 3.

S5.T4.3.3.caption: ChrF++ scores obtained when swapping out the Positional Embeddings and fine-tuning, evaluated across  . N  denotes a direct transition (without any tuning) to No-Positional Embeddings, R  denotes a direct transition to Rotary Positional Embeddings, and A  denotes a direct transition to ALiBi Positional Embeddings. “FFT” represents Full Fine-Tuning, “L” signifies LoRA fine-tuning, and “ML” refers to minimalistic LoRA fine-tuning (applied exclusively to the Self-Attention block).
S5.T4.3.3.table:
Base SINE NoPE RoPE ALiBi
IT2 N∗ R∗ A∗ FFT L ML FFT L ML FFT L ML FFT L ML
Flores Indic-En 59.5 34.9 31.5 23.3 59.6 59.2 59.3 42.8 41.7 41 59.4 59.0 59.0 59.3 58.7 58.7
IN22-Conv Indic-En 55.8 38.6 38.0 35.0 55.8 55.6 55.6 44.8 44.3 43.7 55.6 55.3 55.4 55.3 55.1 55.2
IN22-Gen Indic-En 62.0 34.1 28.0 19.5 61.9 61.6 61.6 42.5 41.1 40.3 61.6 61.4 61.3 60.7 60.9 60.8
Flores En-Indic 47.9 31.5 27.0 15.9 48.1 47.7 47.5 39.0 37.6 36.6 48.2 47.7 47.5 49.4 47.6 47.5
IN22-Conv En-Indic 44.5 35.2 31.3 26.1 42.4 42.0 42.5 38.7 37.5 37.2 42.5 42.0 42.0 42.8 42.0 42.1
IN22-Gen En-Indic 48.3 30.1 24.9 13.4 46.3 46.1 46.7 36.9 35.1 33.7 46.3 46.2 46.0 46.4 46.0 45.9
references:
Tables 4 and 5 demonstrate the performance of several experimental setups that involve swapping of Positional Embeddings and followed by fine-tuning (if applicable).
Tables 6 and 7 demonstrate the performance trends of the models with the respective Positional Embedding trained from scratch. We compare these with the results in Tables 4 and 5. The comparison shows that models with swapped Positional Embeddings either outperform or are on par with their counterparts trained from scratch. However, training from scratch is resource-intensive, whereas the proposed approach of post-hoc Positional Embedding swapping proves to be a more efficient alternative in terms of both computation and data. Additionally, models trained from scratch using NoPE slightly outperform their swap counterparts, but remain suboptimal compared to any other Positional Embeddings (SINE / ALiBi / RoPE), further reinforcing the prior finding that NoPE is not a viable option for Encoder-Decoder models.

Tables 4 and 5 demonstrate the performance of several experimental setups that involve swapping of Positional Embeddings and followed by fine-tuning (if applicable).
Tables 6 and 7 demonstrate the performance trends of the models with the respective Positional Embedding trained from scratch. We compare these with the results in Tables 4 and 5. The comparison shows that models with swapped Positional Embeddings either outperform or are on par with their counterparts trained from scratch. However, training from scratch is resource-intensive, whereas the proposed approach of post-hoc Positional Embedding swapping proves to be a more efficient alternative in terms of both computation and data. Additionally, models trained from scratch using NoPE slightly outperform their swap counterparts, but remain suboptimal compared to any other Positional Embeddings (SINE / ALiBi / RoPE), further reinforcing the prior finding that NoPE is not a viable option for Encoder-Decoder models.

The comparison shows that models with swapped Positional Embeddings either outperform or are on par with their counterparts trained from scratch.
